awd_titl_txt: Notions of time and medical decision-making
awd_abstract_narration:
Scientific studies of decision-making have established that concepts such as urgency and risk vary widely among individuals and across cultures. Medical decision-making depends on how associated concepts are interpreted by both the sick and their caretakers. This research examines how distinct cultural notions of time and timescale shape medical decision making, using diabetes-related complications as a case study to question how interpretations of time influence health decisions and outcomes. The research is informed by and advances anthropological theories of temporality. The project also trains U.S. undergraduate students. 

This project will investigate how social, cultural, and demographic factors affect notions of time and how these, in turn, shape medical risk. Diabetes complications often begin with mundane symptoms that rapidly develop into dramatic, life changing events. Using interviews and participant observation, this study examines how people living with diabetes seek care from multiple sources and in relation to acute versus chronic manifestations of the disease. Patient-centered data will further be contextualized by interviews with healthcare providers and participant observation in diabetes clinics. The researcher will provide evidence of 1) why and when specific providers or sets of providers are selected; and 2) how these caretakers' notions of time interact with diabetes complications to affect medical decision-making and outcomes. Understanding diverse stakeholder perspectives will inform theories of medical decision-making by shifting the focus from the individual life-course to incorporate multi-generational and community perspectives.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Behavioral and Cognitive Sciences

por.por_cntn:
This project explored how cultural notions of time and timescales influence medical decision-making, with a focus on diabetes-related complications. Using interviews and participant observation with patients and healthcare providers, the study examined how social, cultural, and demographic factors shape interpretations of medical risk and care-seeking behaviors. By contextualizing patient-centered data with provider perspectives, the research advances anthropological theories of temporality and informs medical decision-making frameworks that incorporate multi-generational and community perspectives. The project also trained U.S. undergraduate students in research methods.

The intellectual merit of this project advances anthropological understandings of biomedical responsibility and autonomy by examining how cultural notions of temporality shape medical decision-making and health outcomes, particularly in the context of diabetes complications. Using ethnographic and qualitative methods in Samoa, a field site uniquely suited to studying multiple healing temporalities and intergenerational health perspectives, the project contributes to theories of temporality in medical anthropology and offers insights into the dynamics of prevention and care across diverse medical systems.

The key theoretical insights developed from this project revolve around the role of temporality in how symptoms are culturally constructed, how symptom knowledge is formed socially and intergenerationally, and that global health interventions that take a knowledge-only approach to diabetes reproduce social inequalities in a way that may contribute to rising rates of complications.

Its broader impacts proposed were to improve strategies to manage undiagnosed diabetes, challenging individualistic prevention models by emphasizing cultural and systemic factors, and informing healthcare provider training and policies. Additionally, the project supports the development of future researchers through student training and mentoring in qualitative social science methods.

The project findings will contribute to global health conversations about how to develop diabetes interventions. The project demonstrates the knowledge gaps that are produced when diabetes care is defined by prevention-heavy, knowledge-dominant approaches. The findings disseminated will offer alternatives to individualistic, knowledge only approaches, including a life-course approach to diabetes care.

 


Last Modified: 01/07/2025
Modified by: Jessica Hardin
